header.title: THE HELLENIC MYSTERY TAROT of Hermes
header.category: Western Esotericism, Tarot, Hermeticism, Divination, Mythology

central_thesis: The book reinterprets traditional Tarot archetypes through the lens of Hellenic and Roman mythology, systematically mapping these revised cards onto the Qabalistic Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetsirah, Assiah) to provide a rich, multi-layered system for divination, self-analysis, and understanding of natural and spiritual processes, bridging classical paganism with Hermetic Qabalah.

structure_content.summary: Represents the unborn soul's decision to incarnate, a 'Portal' where the cave is the womb of the universe. 'Higher Consciousness' (Phebus/the sun) looks in, as the young Phoebus, having enjoyed a single life, decides whether to cross the threshold into domesticity, embodied by the woman, children, and old man he will become. This is the archetypal Fool.

Concerns agriculture, wills, inheritance, and death by old age. It signifies descent from higher to lower realms for practical benefits and conflicts between generations. The children in the cavern are the four seasons. Saturn, Father Time, is depicted as sleeping yet always awake. It calls for vigilance and measured consideration, identified as 'Death in Assiah' on the Earth Enochian Chessboard.

structure_content.chapter_title: 3 The Hanged Man in Assiah (path of saturn)
structure_content.summary: Indicates the necessity for patience regarding a question, emphasizing the proverb 'Do not act in haste'. It signifies the slow, unstoppable passage of time, the planetary path of Saturn, and annual and longer-term time cycles. Patience is required, and it can also represent delay.

Depicts two suns and two aspects of Janus/Ianus, symbolizing knowledge and light from both heaven and earth, as this deity has free access to both realms. It implies dualities, eternal aspects of age and youth, the four seasons represented by four faces, and the year by a serpent. This 'taro' points to comprehensive knowledge, both mundane and practical, and spiritual awareness within Atziluth, the world of archetypes.

Emphasizes the need for permissions and preliminary work before approaching the 'Higher Worlds' or Heaven, with Ianus serving as the gatekeeper of the gods. To govern oneself and others, one must emulate the sun's light, radiance, and understanding. It advises approaching authority correctly and appropriately, recognizing Janus's presence in this world as a starting point for mysteries.

Represents Apollo, who governs all aspects of nature under the Sun, signifying joy, life, ecology, and environmental harmony. It relates to procreation, growth, biological evolution, and general good fortune. This 'Sun in Assiah' card symbolizes higher faculties and powers grounded in the physical realm, connecting to the Earth chessboard, and encompassing animal, vegetable, and human kingdoms.

structure_content.chapter_title: 7 High Priestess in Assiah (fountain of youth)
structure_content.summary: Features Hêbê, the goddess of youth (Roman Juventas) and cupbearer to the gods. She is an aspect of the High Priestess, seated within the Temple's portal, before the veil. This veil symbolizes primordial matter and the web of the universe, with Hêbê representing life energy (Chi), through which one may partake of divine sustenance.

Known as the 'Ship of the Sun', this card presents a juxtaposition of Fire and Water, potentially representing the Sun reflected by the sea or light filtered through water. It suggests a need to look or explore beneath the surface of matters and straddles all Four Worlds. Its imagery originates from Dynastic Egypt, associated with the Solar Bark of Ra.

Depicts Mithras, the Sun, either guiding or contending with the Moon (a white cow). The background includes an Egyptian Sceptre with an all-seeing eye, identified as Shiva's eye, which purges sin and destroys evil. Practically, it suggests achieving balance between diurnal and nocturnal activities, representing the Mithraic mystery school and tradition, and highlighting awareness of all life aspects, including hidden or shaded elements.

Signifies strength derived from clarity of purpose, facilitated by the cleansing power of the Sun. Adad and Adargate demonstrate strength through their close relationship. The subjugated lion is Leo. Apolline, with his distinctive appearance, embodies celestial fire and victory, holding a flower symbolizing beauty.

Divinatory factors revolve around the need to subjugate lower impulses through the mind or higher super-rational self. The measuring stick implies accuracy, detail, and the necessity of self-judgment for one's actions. The card also addresses the proper proportioning of time and judging life stages. Serapis, a fusion of Greek Osiris and the Apis Bull, is presented as a supreme god of the Underworld.

Presents a deity presiding over the four elements, determining their mixture and proportions to rain upon Earth. In personal life, it signifies making similar choices, embodying alchemy, both external and internal. The halo represents the divine light of the Sun, another ingredient governed by Phoebus. This card corresponds to the Enochian Chess Fire Board, 'The Magician in Atziluth'.

Represents Thoth-Hermes and Apollo, both revered as Gods of medicine, with Esculapio, son of Apollo, also depicted. Named 'remedy' rather than 'medicine', it suggests solutions to puzzles, problems, or psychological dilemmas. The card is rich in resources, symbolizing the teaching of medicine, and the beneficial use of herbs and diet.

structure_content.chapter_title: 14 The Sun in Yetsirah (the radiant one)
structure_content.summary: Shows the Sun holding a torch, which symbolically banishes or creates mists, rising as humidity from seas or earth. Phoebus carries a shield, representing both protection and light. The crowned Phoebus, steering the Ram with fire, symbolizes control over the animal or lower self, and powers related to heat and humidity. This card is associated with the mists and humidities of the air.

Represents lunar flows and the need for precise timing in activities. 'Hunting' can signify aspects of providing through work or recreational sport, particularly activities associated with the night. Isis, cloaked in black sable, symbolizes the smallest moon segments, while Diana with her firebrand signifies the period around the full moon.

Concerns travel, disguises, destinations, and choices of direction. The two depicted deities offer significant signs in these matters, drawing from both lunar and solar influences. Hecate, though seemingly a dark goddess, can provide valuable help and advice, which must be balanced with solar guidance. The sparrow or sparrow hawk may represent Jupiter or Apollo depending on context. It is an Assiah card, strongly linked to Earth and crossroads.

The billowing dresses of Isis symbolize the ebbs and tides caused by the moon. This card is deeply connected to moisture and the moon's effects via air, across land and water. Beyond the literal tides (represented by two Isis figures for low and high tide), it can also suggest Tattvic and Astral tides in human life.

structure_content.chapter_title: 18 The World in Atziluth (soul of the world)
structure_content.summary: This 'Taro 4W' illustrates the divine harmony underlying the experiential universe. Jupiter assumes the role of a supreme deity, with Pan connecting this essence to reality. It signifies a valuable resource. Jove, seated beneath a tree like Buddha, suggests meditation through sound or mantras.

Embodies wisdom and rulership (or modern management), encompassing intellect, decision-making, communication, and sound. Jove in flight signifies a creator, aligned with Egyptian assignments to the universe's circle and governmental regality. Enthroned, he wears a commander's garment, holding Victoria and the Eagle. Jove walks on Air, hence Yetsirah.

Alternatively named 'the summoning,' implying obligation when the King of the Gods invites. The mood is celebratory, indicative of a wedding (of Mercury and Philogia), music, and wealth. Jove is at his highest aspect, fully arrayed. Pragmatically, it portends new opportunities or important events, with Jove witnessing an Oath, promising prosperity and new knowledge.

Represents both aspects of a bargain: the pleasures and responsibilities of marriage or relationships, focusing on wedding vows and the pragmatic side of child-rearing. Jove Horcio, 'Fidio', from the Roman panel, signifies the oath of Love: Amor, Onor, Veritas. Saette, a child with horns, is nursed by the Amaltea goat. The other figure, adorned with Bacchus's symbols, holds a wine goblet and an Eagle wand.

Signifies gain achieved after struggle, often requiring physical strength or manual labor. Hercules, winning a trophy from a powerful woman and giving it to his wife, suggests providing for a beloved through effort. It may also indicate a need for a forceful, though potentially inelegant, resolution. It warns of dangers associated with wielding a weapon, as seen with Rippolta and King Caudales' guard. This Assiah card represents brute force.

structure_content.chapter_title: 23 The High Priestess in Yetsirah (wind of change)
structure_content.summary: Iris, being capricious, can bring sudden or unexpected change. The card's emblematic qualities are profound: a ship that weighs nothing in water but is a heavy object over land, requiring effort. The unconventional method of ship travel through air suggests considering unusual modes of change and exploring more possibilities, indicating flexibility and swift action.

Concerns Jupiter's secrets from Juno and Hercules's role, depicted in two aspects: wearing animal skins and a ceremonial toga. His bare feet are grounded, while a bust of Hercules on a pedestal signifies remoteness. This remoteness can be physical (wandering a desolate landscape) or academic/social (isolated position). It also means 'action at a distance,' like remote-control.

Represents wealth in its positive and negative aspects. Juno, wife of the Emperor (Zeus/Jupiter), is associated with Briah (Water), signified by the Peacock, implying that this card focuses on the enjoyment, display, and luxury of wealth, rather than its acquisition.

structure_content.chapter_title: 26 The Empress in Assiah (from the earth)
structure_content.summary: Depicts Juno both enthroned and standing, crowned as The Empress. She carries a basket of produce and holds fruit. Her aspect as Air is shown by a winged figure and lightning bolts, indicating control over weather. She embodies the quintessential provider of life's needs, representing Juno as the Earth mother in this Earth-aligned Assiah card.

Shows Castor and Pollux, twin stars and brothers, riding slowly and conversing, with spears pointing heavenward. This card suggests a need for both relaxation and readiness. It implies a twinned or joined purpose, emphasizing communication and empathy. It may indicate a question involving twinned fates or a shared endeavor.

Illustrates three aspects of Juno, focusing on marriage, mistrust, and antagonism within family relationships. Juno, representing the height of summer, holds the fetters of marriage. Her springtime aspect (left) tramples Hercules's lion skin, indicating jealousy. Her autumnal aspect (right) wears Bacchus's goatskin with disdain. As Jupiter's wife betrayed by his sons with other women, it signifies the prospect of children or material prosperity, though with difficulties.

Connected with Justice in marriage and the mythology of Himeneo and Juno, it signifies perpetual and indissoluble marriage. Proceeds are distributed among children, watched by a bird (heavens/Gods). Divinatory, it represents divinely proportioned resource distribution. Himeneo observes the earth, leaves proceeds, and departs. This card relates to inherited wealth, family fortunes, and the earth.

An important card representing the goddess Ops and her Chariot. The cube and dice in the foreground are sacred to Cybele (Ops). She is mistress of magic and logistics. Her turreted crown, wand, and lions (signifying fire) direct events. Accompanied by an army of followers, her Chariot is a mobile source of power, bringing motivation and action.

Represents pilgrimage, with background workers and supporting personnel who follow, join, and execute groundwork and logistics. It suggests fans following a religion, team, or band. Hard work (Taurus) is implied, with celebration and noise (musicians guiding the procession). Progress is slow, often uphill or through mud, and one might be swept along by the crowd to an unintended destination.

Depicts the Temple of the Vestal virgins, sacred to the Earth goddess Vesta (also Ops and Proserpine), inaccessible to men. It symbolizes sanctuary from the world and connects with emotions and pure love. This astral or celestial temple remains clean and pure. Placed in Briah (emotional, creative realm), it associates with the Abbess/Priestess as matron, creation, and mastery of inner mysteries.

The Searcher. Ceres represents modern technology and industry, drawn on a chariot by fiery dragons. She is shown in two aspects: actively searching with a torch for Proserpine (taken to the underworld by Pluto) and passively mourning as a horse-headed figure at the cavern entrance to the underworld. It concerns the balance of activity and inactivity, knowing when to wait or move, and the process of seeking and gathering knowledge.

structure_content.chapter_title: 34 The High Priestess in Briah (the flow)
structure_content.summary: Signifies femininity, child-rearing, and fertility, with both female figures pregnant. The card alludes to the lunar cycle and flow, and harmony with nature. A goose, possessing magical properties, helps initiate the flow of events. A snake at the cave entrance may represent danger, male sexuality, carnal knowledge, or the entrance to the underworld (Proserpine and Pluto).

Symbolizes being seduced onto a false path, encountering dangerous rocks, and suffering shipwreck and destruction. The beauty and music of the Sirens are deceptive, representing a negative aspect of the Muses (T4W 87). It serves as a caution against love cheats and seducers.

Concerns shipping, sea-travel, and naval affairs. It is a beneficent card, representing victory over the Tritons. Aphrodite's presence is favorable for matters of love and childbirth, being under Neptune's protection. The Chariot, shaped like a shell, symbolizes sonic power and distant communication.

Represents fire quenched by water and water's nourishing power bringing life to earth. On a basic level, it signifies instructions for reclaiming the Nile (or estuaries) for cultivation through canal building. A coiled, perforated tube could symbolize an intestinal hose for water distribution without evaporation, also acting as a fire defense (wax melts to extinguish). Success demands industry and ingenuity.

Juxtaposes two Nereides, one more virtuous and womanly than the other, predominantly a fish. Beyond a morality tale of unbridled promiscuity, it carries the general message of moderation inherent to Temperance. Eurimone improves her status, while Dercato regresses. This is the most Watery aspect of Temperance.

structure_content.chapter_title: 39 The World in Yetsirah (the four winds)
structure_content.summary: Depicts the four winds and their influences: Austro (upper left) governs rain, clouds, storms; Borea (upper right) rapes Orizia, with serpent tails, bringing cold and snow; Flora and Zefiro (lower left) represent spring and blooming flowers, earth; Euro or Levante (lower right) signifies the sun and red sunset, blowing by day. This design illustrates the cycle of weather, seasons, human life, and fertility, as winds are the air sustaining life.

Refers to bowls of water used for divination, symbolizing Italian rivers. Hidden meanings resonate with the Narcissus myth and dreams evoked by soothing flowing water. It represents daydreams and inner reflection, suggesting personal and artistic musings, characterizing 'The Star in the World of Water, Briah'.

Depicts an empire at its zenith, though the emperor appears past his prime, yet prolific in bringing children into the world. Vertumno is linked to Bacchus (Dionysus), who brings provisions, well-being, wine, and celebrations. A statue of the mighty Nile (a metaphor for great rivers), signified by a crocodile, is present.

Shows Pluto and Proserpine enthroned, with two nymphs bearing infernal symbols. Pluto wears a black ebony crown, an invisible helm, and a staff to govern spirits. A key holds Hades's doors closed. Cerberus, with three heads and a snake tail, is a witness. Eurimono, seated on a vulture skin, eats dead men. This card warns of evildoers' fate in the afterlife.

Signifies the meaning of 'fury,' as Furies (Alecto, Tisifone, Megera) inflict pain on evil souls for Pluto, thus being neutral. It warns against temper explosions and advises examining emotional motivations. They embody three evils, wearing dead men's skins and snakes on their heads, blood-spotted dresses, snake belts, and torches emitting red blood, aligning with the Earth board, Qabalistic World of Assiah.

The victim is not necessarily male, nor are the poisoners female. 'Poison' can mean gossip, lies, or false witness, relating to poisonous intent. It warns against falseness and maliciousness. The Harpies of Strofadi, with women's heads and bird bodies, punish evil men, embodying a warning against malevolence.

structure_content.chapter_title: 45 The Hanged Man in Yetsirah (thread of life)
structure_content.summary: Depicts Cloto, Lachesi, and Atropo, the three Fates and Pluto's servants, spinning and cutting the thread of a person's life. It suggests reflecting on one's past life as if it were complete, with the thread being that from which the Hanged Man is suspended. These winged servants from the world of the dead communicate, with Cloto representing Unity and interweaving, Lachesi overseeing lots and chance, and Atropo governing mundane events.

Shows the goddess Necessity with her daughters, the Parche or Fates. The spindle is connected to the starry heavens, with its diamond axis extending from pole to pole of Earth. The Goddess embodies the facts of necessity in all aspects of life. The friction from turning the diamond could generate heat or fire, aligning with the Fire Chessboard in Atziluth.

Warns that those grieving for the dead could easily join them, urging vigilance against the unforeseen, though it is difficult. This is a memento mori, with a winged messenger bringing comfort to the living. Cupped hands can either stifle grief or act as its receptacle.

Mercury stands naked at a cliff edge, embodying the Tarot Fool's optimism and inexperience. With a hand on a mountain goat and a rooster at his feet, he wears symbols of his function as messenger and protector of merchants. The goddess Peace (Concord) holds infant Pluto, God of riches, and ears of fecundity. This card, eponymous with 'Peace', highlights the need for diplomacy, negotiation, and enlightened governance to maintain this desirable state.

The Faith (Ceres) is fully veiled, symbolizing candidness of mind. The goddess Peace or Concord is represented by her cup and cornucopia. The swan and cornacchia signify marital fidelity. It allegorizes 'descent' from virginity into marriage, yet also hints at sorrow if the union isn't ideal. It signifies adolescence to adulthood, parental anxiety, and associated challenges.

Features Mercury with his daughter Arena ('Sport' or 'Fight') and the column quadrant (Herma). Thoth of Egypt, inventor of table-games, is here in his Greek incarnation, father of 'Sport.' It highlights the close link between body and mind, where emotional upset affects physical ability. Success in mental pursuits requires physical attention. Being adept at sport demands strength, endurance, and mental understanding, reflecting Hermes as Magician concerned with recreation and creative play.

structure_content.chapter_title: 51 The Hermit in Atziluth (the virtuous do not fear)
structure_content.summary: States that bringing light also conceals darkness. Its divinatory meaning is precisely 'the virtuous do not fear.' One Herma has an erect penis, towards which two flaccid Herma gaze, signifying not being afraid of or subjugating the sexual drive, and perhaps indicating that anxiety can cause impotence.

Depicts Night, mother of sleep and death, shrouded in darkness with an overcast Moon. This 'taro' addresses practical matters of sleep, shelter, and safety. Night, seated on the earth and not enthroned, nurtures, but the purest intellects abandon night for day, lest their creations become distorted. Her vestments are star-covered. Divination concerns nocturnal situations, specific to the Moon in Assiah, Earth chessboard.

Illustrates different forms of Hermes and Hermanubis. Their grounded feet signify their role in rearing, safeguarding, and sacrificing sheep. Hermanubis is the protector of the dying and god of the underworld. Hermes guides the soul into sleep and the afterlife. Divinatory, it advises vigilance in everyday life, to adopt the roles of a shepherd/sheepdog, and to observe from all directions.

Shows Hercules with lion skin, mace, and bow—symbols of force. Thin strands of gold represent eloquence's power to attract. The woman clutching her heart signifies emotional, intentional strength over physical power. Hercules' weapons symbolize arguments, not just physical might. It warns that malicious words can harm as much as encouraging words can help, asserting that the power of truth overshadows propaganda.

Hercules, a formidable combatant and drinker, receives a goblet from a young person. An altar with another bowl symbolizes sustenance for the gods or Hercules's divinity. The card represents situations requiring offerings or sacrifices, impasse, suspension, and the passage of time, necessitating loss to achieve goals. Hercules's two aspects in different costumes represent his 'masculine' and 'feminine' qualities.

Depicts bowls of water for divination, indicating struggles, arguments, politics, and contradictory divinations. Two figures contend for control, unable to use the tripod. Apollo and Hercules vie for the Oracle, while Minerva, Latona, and Diana calm them, seeking Minerva's judgment. Womanly advice can ameliorate confrontational male approaches. Minerva, bearing the Sphinx, can answer the conundrum.

Figuratively represents the birth of a plan, idea, or concept involving Zeus. The brother and sister relationship mirrors the Caduceus's twin snakes. Minerva's spear, pointing upwards, conducts divine energy, and both spear and Caduceus symbolize the spine and Kundalini energy. This 'T4W' represents a union of Shakti and Shiva (male and female), even showing role-reversal with a man giving birth without a woman.

structure_content.chapter_title: 58 The High Priestess in Atziluth (study & practice)
structure_content.summary: Minerva (Athena) is an alternative name for this card, titled 'study and practice' to reflect the stages of preparation, work, and final dressing. Each stage must be satisfactorily completed. A small central figure appears to unify Minerva's three aspects (wisdom), potentially representing an inner voice or younger self. It advises study (theory), practice, and vigilance.

Male Virtue stands beside female Honour (with spear, horn of doves, and a helmet underfoot). This card warns of an impending assault but advises calmness through preparation. Virtue and Honour must unite to resist adversaries. In modern context, it may suggest litigation. The tortoise, an ancient symbol, implies retreat and emphasizes slow but steady progress.

Harpocrates (young Horus) is depicted with a finger to his mouth, symbolizing mystical silence, oath-observance, and secret-keeping in the Egyptian pantheon. Angerona, on her immortal plinth, represents the ability to bear suffering silently. A third figure, Harpocrates covered in wolf skin with many eyes and ears, signifies the need to observe and hear much, but speak little.

Represents an earthy, smoky 'Tower' aspect, showing war equipment destroyed by fire, reminiscent of rats gnawing through leather straps. Vulcan (Ptah), artificer of the gods, controls rats in the underworld. The King/Pharaoh in Ptah's temple prioritizes religion. Alchemically, it conveys forging/melting armor, shedding old 'skins,' and phoenix-like rising.

The goddess Reputation (Fame) is depicted running swiftly with a bugle and wings. She flies day and night from high towers, capable of scaring people with bad news or lightly delivering news. Positioned before Mars' chariot, she listens and comments on events, needing little from Mars to ignite minds. This card explains how fame or media influence is achieved.

This stark and bleak symbol embodies a fiery, destructive male deity. The weapon, though useful for defense or attack, is best stored as depicted. The empty plinth symbolizes humanity destroyed by war, admonishing those who commemorate martial figures. It represents all that remains after the Tower's destruction by lightning or fire.

Victoria is winged, crowned with bay or olive, and has an eagle at her feet, which flies most powerfully. She also appears as Minerva, wingless, holding a helmet. Achieving Victory requires overcoming fear and horror, with Minerva (wisdom) as the best companion. Victory holds the crown and helmet but does not wear them, suggesting knowing when to fly or stand firm. It emphasizes learning qualities of the eagle and sphinx, always keeping ultimate Victory in mind.

Depicts Bacchus as a child covered in knotted vine leaves and grapes, signifying that wine reveals what is hidden. Bacchus, with small horns and often accompanied by a panther, embodies drinking and merry-making. The card contrasts a young man setting out with the old man he becomes, suggesting meditation on one's future self, and highlighting physical decline accelerated by excessive lifestyle.

Comus, the God of convivial ones, is youthful and joyful. Flowers symbolize joy and 'spensieratezza' at banquets. He supports himself with a staff due to unsteadiness after abundant celebrations. At a wedding feast, he is unsure whether to enter the hall, indicating unsteadiness, weakness, and indecision, though not sorrowful. Emotions, possibly wine or drugs, suspend necessary action.

Bacchus, with horns, first taught oxen use; the goat is sacred. The scythe protects cultivations and prunes lives. He is the child of winter solstice, young in spring equinox, and the old man of summer/autumn. He follows Arianna (his spouse after Teseo's abandonment), accompanied by Satyrs, Nymphs, and Sileni. This card highlights how advances in cultivation and yearly planning formed the 'nuclear' family.

Arianna, with Nymphs, Satyrs, and Sileni, celebrates Bacchus's mysteries. However, she shows signs of weariness from over-partying. Her gaze towards her feet and her companions' cloven feet suggest lower, animalistic natures. Arianna ponders her future, conveying a message that lifestyle changes are needed to prevent excess and weariness from leading to destruction.

Features three favored Dionysian transports: a speedy chariot, a stately elephant, and Bacchus embarking on foot with a staff (others returning). It highlights the importance of ancient trade (especially wine) and idea exchange. Communication or travel by earth or air is indicated, signifying a departure from a current state or place. Bacchus's optimism suggests a revelatory, self-chosen journey.

Depicts Bacchus's ship with a panther prow, side-drums for noise, and ivy, vines, and grapes covering the rows and mast. A wineskin fountain fills amphorae for Satyrs and followers, who subsequently fall drunk into the sea. The red sail features gold-woven Baccanti dancing on Timolo mount in Lydia.

Presents a Greek interpretation of Osiris's battle with Set/Typhon. Typhon, as a crocodile, embodies the amorphous and predatory sexual nature of the Devil. His ambition reaches the stars, but his narrow feet make him unstable. The Hippo and Horse signify Osiris's ability to tame and 'ride' dreams. Osiris can also transform into a bird and, with Thoth and Isis, attain immortality and underworld rulership. Snakes on Typhon's fingers represent deception and illusion.

Priapus is depicted as a positive, divine force representing fertility, akin to Egyptian gods like Min, who masturbates to fertilize the world. The mountain goat symbolizes the earth-bound. Priapus's head sprouts a plant, reinforcing this earthy association. This 'Taro 4W' represents male sexuality, for both good and ill.

The Lari are venerated at crossroads, with trees adorned with balls and wool figures. Dressed in dog skins with their faithful dog, the Lari lead spirits of dead men, wandering and hunting for bodies. They also care for houses and cities, using balls and figures to distract wanderers or household heads. The 'Suffered ones' are adored in sacred places, symbolized by curved sticks or crooks with an earth vase containing sacred mysteries.

Two younger Bacchus figures gesture toward an old man who looks harrowed toward the heavens. A snake fleeing behind a rock and an animal codpiece symbolize dried-up sexual prowess. A bowl of wine is offered, but Bacchus's averted gaze suggests it should not be taken.

Fortune brings well-being and happiness, with a light complexion, guiding a rudder that symbolizes her governance of all things. Her cornucopia dispenses wealth. Her negative aspect manifests as evil and misadventure. The seated figure is past Fortune, the one holding her hand is present Fortune, and the small child is future Fortune. Lattanzio stated people primarily make their own luck, and trusting fate risks encountering Fortune's bad aspect. It can be seen as 'Generations'.

Features two forms of Nemesis, daughter of Justice or Night. As Night's daughter (T4W 52), she can bring vendetta and punishment, flying with wings to catch up with all, controlling Fortune (the wheel) and governance (Taro 75 rudder). As Justice's daughter, she holds a horse's bridle to curb speech and a wooden meter to ensure measured action.

Goddess Justice is young, beautiful, yet terrible. Her sight is acute, seeing everywhere. She holds a dark balance and 'verghe' (branches), a symbol from Roman triumphs. In Cipsello, two carved women represent Justice and 'Ingiuria' (defamation/slander), with Justice holding the latter's neck. This signifies Justice as a punisher of liars and slanderers, impartial and not blindfolded.

The Anchor, child of Hermes and Fortune, is depicted as blind and crazy, holding a 'timone' (miniature rudder) for world governance. It concerns navigation and the replacement of incomplete knowledge (the blankness of the globe) through discovery and mapmaking. His name is cryptically hidden in the design. These alchemical landscapes are intended to be read as Emblemata.

A quote from Richard Linche (1599) describes Fortune's 'unstained and changing mutability,' her sudden and swift departure from those she favored, and her constant flight from destiny. It states that Fortune and Destiny can never align, and where Destiny sets foot, Fortune becomes enchanted and without power, efficacy, or virtue.

Young Allegro is well-dressed, holding a goblet, an ear of wheat, and a poppy. Favour, young, blind, and timid, is touched by Flattery. Flattery, with wings, raises the wheel of Fortune, but if he falls in luck, he falls low again. Invidia, an old woman, watches, envying others' happiness. Happiness, or Fortuna, is seated on her pedestal, embodying virtue and riches, but happiness is not permanent.

Sometimes termed 'sibling rivalry,' where Aphrodite gave Anteros to Eros as a playmate. Eros attempts to wrestle a palm branch, symbolizing a battle to show more love. If love is absent, neither can succeed. Young Leteo extinguishes his torch in the Lete river, signifying that love can easily flow away. It is gender-neutral, potentially representing two rivals for a woman or two women in rivalry over a man.

Known as 'Eros,' God of Romance and Fertility, enduring and governing the erotic. Eros (left) holds arrows for falling in love and keys to hearts. The central figure uses a bow-string motion to cast lightning bolts or feathers, or coax melody from a viola of love. The third figure holds gold arrows for love or lead for indifference. The spark is lost until he picks up the torch. It advises using charm, wit, and seduction, not force.

Aphrodite's wagon is pulled by two doves (lascivious symbols) and two innocent swans. Venus holds a knot, signifying readiness for love or sealing relationships. Undressed, she reveals her charms to those seeking pleasure. She has a torch on her chest, a round ball/egg, and three fruits. An Omphallus on the altar symbolizes libido's birth from the navel. Spirals suggest the labyrinth or umbilical cord. This card relates to female sexuality, akin to Priapus (T4W 72) for males.

Jocus, a strange clownish figure held by Cupid, is given to Venus as a child. ElderVenus sits on a goat with her foot on a tortoise, implying women are predestined to govern the household. Divination may suggest which partner takes household or employment roles, without necessarily endorsing traditional domestic sex roles.

structure_content.chapter_title: 85 The Star in Yetsirah (three in one)
structure_content.summary: Titled 'Trias in Monade, Three in One' in a 1614 version, depicting various aspects of Venus/Aphrodite. Linche reports that Venus, Juno, Luna, and Proserpina were different names for the same entity with diverse effects. The star-gazing Venus holding Victory plans and navigates. The middle figure produces and sustains the earth, while the third figure guards and is vigilant.

Depicts a bleak, winter scene of Adonis slain and Venus grieving, her light veiled. She appears as a bearded man in a dress, symbolizing gender reversal. She holds a comb, signifying her ability to generate males/females or a legend of falling hair/women. The boar, killer of Adonis, represents the Usurper. It evokes dark emotions, sexual uncertainty, fetish, or perversion, usable for self-analysis and correction. The veil symbolizes the earth in winter.

The Archetypal Star; Apollo-Jupiter leads the four Graves, also representing the four seasons. The similarity between harp and bow signifies Apollo-Jupiter's capacity to create harmony or destruction. The 'Thanks' or 'Hours' indicate the four seasons with garlands of flowers, wheat, grapes, and olives. He leads the Muses, conducting stars/planets by his harp's sound or bow's force.

The three Thanks or Muses are guided by Mercury, who imparts reason and healthy speech. This card prioritizes knowledge and truth, revealing justice beyond superficial beauty. Apollo and Mercury were rivals in love. It advises consulting a sage or wise person for understanding complex issues. As the final 'taro', it can signify a farewell or a beckoning to follow.

key_concepts.definition: The Qabalistic levels of existence (Atziluth, Briah, Yetsirah, Assiah) used to categorize and interpret the tarot cards, adding depth to their meanings based on their energetic and material associations.
The Archetypal World, associated with pure spirit and archetypes. Cards here deal with fundamental decisions, divine harmony, and ultimate principles.
The Creative World, associated with emotions, creation, and form. Cards here often relate to inner alchemy, emotional states, and the flow of events.
The Formative World, associated with air, intellect, and communication. Cards here deal with plans, wisdom, subtle energies, and transitions.
The Material World, associated with earth and physical manifestation. Cards here relate to practical matters, physical existence, inheritance, and concrete actions.
The specific tarot cards within this system, designed to integrate Hellenic/Roman mythological figures and concepts into the Qabalistic Four Worlds framework.

A term used to connect certain Assiah cards (e.g., Death in Assiah, The Sun in Assiah, The Moon in Assiah) and The Magician in Atziluth to Enochian magical traditions, suggesting a deeper, elemental association.
Represents the sun, divine radiance, higher consciousness, nature, medicine, and control over elements like mists and humidity. Also signifies light, protection, and harmony.
Associated with the slow, unstoppable passage of time, cycles, patience, delay, and matters of agriculture, wills, and inheritance.
Gatekeeper of the gods, symbolizing duality, access to both heaven and earth, knowledge, and a starting point in mysteries.

A wide array of goddesses, each representing specific aspects such as youth, wealth, maternal roles, wisdom, lunar cycles, love, fertility, justice, and fate, often reinterpreted in multiple contexts across the Four Worlds.
The Magician archetype, representing messenger functions, protection, healing, leading souls, intellect, communication, and creative play.
Symbolizes strength, combat, provision, but also has 'masculine' and 'feminine' aspects, often associated with offerings and overcoming challenges.
Associated with drinking, merry-making, degeneration, family, departure, abundance, and aspects of fertility and lifestyle choices.
Represents the underworld, infernal powers, deception, illusion, predatory nature, and the fate of evildoers.
Spin, measure, and cut the thread of life, symbolizing destiny, chance, and mundane events, often acting as servants of Pluto.

practical_system.description: The system employs a unique tarot deck ('Taro of the Four Worlds') whose cards are explicitly linked to classical Greco-Roman deities, mythological scenes, and philosophical concepts. Each card is assigned to one of the Qabalistic Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetsirah, Assiah), which dictates the level of interpretation (archetypal, creative, formative, material). The system is designed for divination, self-analysis, meditation, and gaining deeper insights into personal actions, universal processes, and spiritual states. It emphasizes the practical benefits of esoteric knowledge, urging the practitioner to consider vigilance, measured consideration, patience, correct approach to authority, balance, and the subjugation of lower impulses.
tools: The 'Taro of the Four Worlds' deck (featuring 1571 engravings by Bolognino Zaltieri)
The accompanying book with detailed mythological and Qabalistic interpretations
Knowledge of Qabalah and the Four Worlds
Understanding of Hellenic and Roman mythology
rituals: Seeking necessary permissions and performing preliminary work (The Hierophant in Assiah)
Exercising vigilance and measured consideration in matters of practical benefit (Death in Assiah)
Exploring beneath the surface of matters through deep introspection (The Sun in Briah)
Overcoming fear and horror to achieve victory through wisdom (Strength in Yetsirah)
Engaging in self-analysis and correction, particularly concerning dark emotions and sexual uncertainties (Death in Briah)
Practicing meditation using sound or mantras for divine harmony (The World in Atziluth)
Adopting shepherd/sheepdog roles and watching all directions for pragmatic life navigation (The Magician in Assiah)
Making personal choices regarding the mixture and proportions of the four elements in one's life (The Magician in Atziluth)

relevant_quotes.text: 1 The Fool in Atziluth. Here is the unborn soul deciding whether to incarnate into nature. Another name for this card is "Portal," and the cave represents the womb of the universe.
2 Death in Assiah. Matters pertaining to agriculture. Wills and inheritance, death by old age. Descent from the higher into the lower when it can bring practical benefits.
3 The Hanged Man in Assiah. The need for patience in matters concerning your question. "Do not act in haste" - I can't improve much on Macrobius' proverb.
4/88 The Sun in Atziluth. The two suns, and two aspects of Ianus or Janus, represent the knowledge and light of heaven and of earth respectively, since this deity has free access to both.
5 The Hierophant in Assiah. Seek necessary permissions, do all preliminary work beforehand. The door is to the Higher Worlds or of Heaven, and Ianus is gatekeeper of the gods.

9 Temperance in Assiah. Mithras, as the Sun, guiding or struggling with the Moon represented as a white cow. In the background we see the Egyptian Sceptre topped with the all-seeing eye. This is the eye of Shiva that when opened purges all sin and destroys evil.
11 Judgment in Atziluth. Divinatory factors revolve around the need to subjugate lower impulses by the mind or higher super-rational self.

12 The Magician in Atziluth. We see what may be construed as the four elements before the deity who decides their mixture and proportions to rain upon the Earth. In our own small lives, we also must make choices of this type.

13 The Magician in Yetsirah. Both Thoth-Hermes and Apollo are reputed as being the God of all medicine. The son of Apollo, Esculapio, is represented here. I named it "remedy” rather than “medicine” because it might also represent the remedy or solution to a puzzle, problem, or psychological dilemma.
21 The Lovers in Assiah. Both sides of a bargain; the pleasures and the responsibilities of marriage or relationships. It concerns the keeping of wedding vows and the pragmatic side of child-raising.
42 The Devil in Atziluth. Pluto and Proserpine are shown enthroned, with two nymphs that bring their symbols of the infernal. ... This card warns of the fate of evildoers in the after-world.

45 The Hanged Man in Yetsirah. Cloto, Lachesi and Atropo, the three Fates, Pluto's servants, spin the life of a person and cut it to length. This card suggests to look backwards at your own life, as if it is already over.
48 The Fool in Yetsirah. Mercury stands at the edge of a cliff. He is naked, and represents the tarot Fool and the optimism of the inexperienced. ... This card is eponymous with the goddess "Peace."
51 The Hermit in Atziluth. To bring forth light is also to conceal the darkness. And the divinatory meaning is precisely what is meant by “the virtuous do not fear."

61 The Tower in Assiah. Earthy and smoky aspect of 'The Tower.' ... An alchemical message is hidden concerning forging and melting down our systems of armour, like shedding a snake-skin, then rising Phoenix-like.

75 Temperance in Assiah. Fortune gives well-being and happiness, has a light complexion, and guides a rudder, symbolizing her sense of the government of all things. Her cornucopia is for dispensing wealth. ... I sometimes think of this card as Generations.

79 Temperance in Yetsirah. “This brief depicturance may unfold unto us the unstained and changing mutability of Fortune, and her sudden & most swift departure from those whom even now she favoured & highly advanced. Or that it signifies, that she is always flying from destiny, seeking all means to avoid her company, for that indeed these two can never accord or agree together: for so much as where Destiny sets her foot, Fortune is there as it were enchanted & conjured, as having no power, efficacy, or virtue." Richard Linche, 1599.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Hellenic Mystery Tarot of Hermes' is a significant contribution to esoteric tarot studies, offering a unique syncretic approach. It moves beyond standard Rider-Waite-Smith or Thoth interpretations by deeply grounding the archetypes in classical Greco-Roman mythology, directly illustrating gods and myths rather than solely symbolic figures. Its explicit mapping to the Qabalistic Four Worlds provides a structured framework for interpretation that links classical paganism with Hermetic Qabalah, offering a powerful tool for practitioners interested in a nuanced, layered understanding of the universe and self. The detailed descriptions for each card, including their practical applications, esoteric correspondences (e.g., Enochian Chessboard), and moral lessons, make it a rich resource for deep magical and divinatory work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Advanced students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Hermetic Qabalah, classical paganism, and experienced tarot readers seeking a historically informed and philosophically deep system. It would appeal to those who value syncretic approaches and wish to integrate classical mythology directly into their magical and divinatory practices, moving beyond purely modern or purely Qabalistic interpretations.
